Claim: All humans should be vegan.
Veganism is a more ethical lifestyle.
If all humans were vegan, animals would not be killed or made to suffer needlessly, which is the moral thing to do.
The animals being slaughtered are often treated cruelly.
A cow's typical life-span is 25 years. Cows used in dairy production are exhausted and for most part killed after 4-5 years.
Animals at farms are treated with the lowest priority when it comes to keeping lives safe during natural disasters. With Hurricane Florence, millions of animals died in factory farms.

When the demand for animal products goes down (like with the coronavirus), farmers just kill all the animals. Unnecessary killing of animals and the wastefulness that comes with it wouldn't take place in a vegan world.
Farmed livestock are protected from threats such as exposure, starvation, disease and predators. Protections that they would not have in the wild.
Protection means nothing when we are their predators and their lives are compromised on restricted grounds.

If cruelty and suffering are concerns, then acquiring meat from a hunter (or similar instant killing method) should be acceptable. In other words, you do not have to go vegan to avoid animal suffering - you just must be certain that your source of meat is cruelty-free.

Killing an animal is not cruelty-free. The cruelty of killing extends to their family if they are part of raising it, as well as dying by having a short life and another being deciding their fate in life for them. Veganism does not create these abuses.
It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly; mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat.
Slaughter areas are designed to keep the cattle calm so they don't pump adrenaline through their veins souring the meat.

The reduction in quality of the product is offset by an increase in quantity produced, resulting in a net increase in revenue. As revenues drive production, meat producers are often incentivized to use cruel methods, even if it somewhat reduces the quality of the product.
Not all forms of cruelty result in inferior quality meat.
It is possible to consume meat in an ethical way.
Scientific advancements such as lab-grown meat make it possible for people to eat meat without harming living animals.
Cultured meat is just as environmentally sustainable as a vertical farm (like 808 factory in Recipes From the Future) for factory farming practices, even though it involves animals.
Lab-grown meat has a massively reduced environmental impact due to not needing to expend energy and water to grow an entire living animal.
Meat derived from living animals can only be consumed by excising it from the animals, which involves slaughter or mutilation, both of which involve unavoidable moral harms.
Eating from small-scale meat and animal product producers is more ethical than consuming the product of industrial farming practices.
There are many humane meat producers.

With regard to the definition (1st one) of humane, killing perfectly healthy animals just because of preference or taste is neither tender nor compassionate and shows no sympathy for the animal. There is no way to kill a human humanely, nor an animal.
There are multiple forms of agriculture and organic farming with animal welfare in mind. Biodynamic agriculture is one example.
Certain forms of privately maintained animal rearing are not harmful, for instance keeping chickens in backyards.
Many meat animals in the third world are part of the family and protected from surrounding predators and only killed when there is need. Animals can be killed individually with minimum pain.

Even in supposedly ethical free-range backyard farming where chickens are not harmed, other animals might be: chickens are omnivores so may consume or otherwise impact insects and other wildlife where they are kept, and thereby disrupt the native ecosystem/food chain there.

Chickens are also non-native, as they're domesticated and only is semi-part of the ecosystem. So every time they enter it, they could disrupt its natural life cycles (like food chains, but also resources, like nitrogen).
Most backyard chickens are still killed for food once they stop laying frequently.
Most backyard chickens are hens (females). Most of the cocks (males) will have been killed at hatching.
It is not feasible to support the world on this small scale farming, thus by not being vegan humans are forced to turn to crueler methods.
Many chickens have been bred to produce more eggs than is healthy for them to do so. Their calcium can become severely depleted, and it is difficult to feed them enough to overcome this.
Such meat producers would never be able to produce enough meat to feed the entire world.
This meat is often more expensive than factory produced alternatives.
Industrial meat from developed countries is cheaper than local meat in most developing countries.
Even locally produced meat involves slaughtering animals for their body parts, which is unethical.

The majority of consumers prioritize the cost and ease of meat rather than the ethics of production. Just because a minority choose to carefully select their produce, does not compensate for a majority who do not.
There is no clear boundary between human and animal suffering, so humans should aim to reduce suffering for animals as they would for humans.

Free range chickens are still slaughtered, selectively bred for rapid growth to a point where for some, their legs can't support them, and kept in overcrowded barns. Free Range doesn't equal a happy life for the animal.
Many people do not have access to or cannot afford ethically produced meat.
Animals have innate, individual rights, which are taken away when they are killed or made to suffer.
Plants do not have rights, as only individuals can have rights and plants are not individuals.
Individuals are indivisible (by definition) yet plants may be divided (e.g. by taking a cutting) and both parts survive happily. Thus, plants are not individuals.
There are good reasons to believe that group rights can exist.
Group rights can only even potentially apply to groups of individuals. But unless plants are individuals (or a collection of individuals), group rights couldn't apply to them.
The distinction between humans and animals from a biological and psychological perspective is small.
Animals have a desire to live.
Animals have a concept of what it's like to be free vs being held in captivity.
Something's desire to live does not imply its right to live. This is the cornerstone of Darwinian survival - everything wants to survive but only the fittest will.
Animals are sentient and have the capacity to suffer, which relates to their having moral value.
Since pain is an evolutionary advantage, animals have evolved to experience suffering.
We should assume that animals are conscious.
Consciousness is a barely understood concept, even in humans, but this does not mean there is no consciousness. Humans act on the assumption consciousness exists for themselves and others.
Humans assume what we interpret from data and evidence. We cannot suppose animals are conscious if they don't show any evidence of it. So we shouldn't act on it until we know for sure.
When we compare the human reactions signalling pain to reactions often expressed by animals when they possibly would feel pain, they are very similar.

We can also assume that farmed animals have no concept of life outside the farm, and since they've never experienced anything but farm life, they would have no reason not to be happy with life on the farm.
Captive animals only suffer when they are aware of their wild counterparts, which they rarely are.
A number of animals have passed the 'Mirror test', proving that they can recognise themselves as an individual.

Differential treatment of whether killing of someone or something for food is admissible must be based on some trait the subject is lacking. Since there's no trait that wouldn't end up us eating humans, we can't treat animal lives differently than human lives.
Animals do not have similar levels of emotional comprehension or intelligence (1, 2) to humans. Therefore they are of less value.
The ability to suffer on a physical or even psychological level is not related or correlated to comprehension/intelligence.
Many mammals can get the same or at least very similar mental conditions as humans, including depression, OCD, anxiety disorders, etc.
There are difficulties in measuring emotional and general intelligence. To base a life's value on subjective ranking does not make sense.
Humans possess few unique abilities or skills and are worse than animals in some respects. This does not make humans less valuable, and the same criteria should be applied to animals.

Animals react to stimuli differently, but still emotionally. Because they react differently, humans do not take it seriously or say their responses even exist or have merit. That is why people do not believe animals are intelligent or smart.
Many animals do not pass the mirror test as a measure of self awareness.
The mirror test is likely a very unreliable test of self awareness.
Since animals do not possess free will in the same way as humans, they can't have any rights (p. 538).
Animals may not have positive rights due to an inability to meaningfully have duties, but they could still have negative rights, for which free will is not necessary.
Infants don't know about or obey any laws, and yet have rights: harming or killing infants is against the law. Animals have or may be given rights in the same way.
Animal lives are of sufficient value that we should not inflict needless suffering onto them when non-animal alternatives exist.
Fur coats are unnecessary for warmth in all conditions, and they also require 15x as much energy to produce than non-fur equivalents.

If one is concerned with numbers of deaths of living organisms, then this argument is actually in support of voluntary suicide via starvation, as many plants must be killed or aborted to support the life of one human being.

When considering morality, it is necessary to draw a line. It is unlikely that most humans would adopt a moral position that requires them to starve themselves to death, therefore it is necessary to strike a balance between surviving and acting ethically.
Plants have no less right to exist on Earth than humans or animals, which negates the vegan moral argument.

Plants have many of the same rights-attracting properties as humans and animals; they can communicate, they can develop social structures, sentience, they can have sex, they can even "walk" or eat "animals".

Veganism is based on the false superiority of animals against plants, while we already know about plant life (like Pando) that is much more complex than sponges (animals). It doesn't make sense for Pando to be considered 'just' food and sponge considered comparatively sacred.

Appeal to extremes / reductio ad absurdum. Vegans do not have to argue that sponges are superior and sacred compared to some plants. The general superiority of animals is not false - some animals that we eat are conscious, sentient beings. No plants are conscious or sentient.
There is research to suggest that plants too can feel pain.
Plants release gases that are the equivalent of crying out in pain. Using a laser-powered microphone, researchers have picked up sound waves produced by plants releasing gases when cut or injured.
Reacting to trauma is not the same as feeling pain. Pain requires some subject to experience the pain and plants plausibly lack this subjectiveness.
Plants can react to pain.

They have neither nervous system nor pain receptors. Plus, although plants have neurotransmitters (even the same as ones found in humans), they do not use it for thinking but instead as protection (by changing their predators' brain chemistry to prevent their attacks).

"Perhaps the cleverest instance of plant signalling involves two insect species, the first in the role of pest and the second as its exterminator. Several species, including corn and lima beans, emit a chemical distress call when attacked by caterpillars. Parasitic wasps some distance away lock in on that scent, follow it to the afflicted plant, and proceed to slowly destroy the caterpillars. Scientists call these insects “plant bodyguards.”" [ link ]
While plants seem not to perform central pain processing, they are still responsive to nociception in ways that reflect aversion.
There is far more evidence that animals can suffer than there is evidence that plants can suffer.
Fruits, for example, are deliberately tasty, so that other organisms consume them and thereby involuntarily distribute the fruits' seeds, as they are not digested, or left on the floor.
Research indicates that plant roots seek out buried pipes through which water is flowing even if the exterior is dry. This suggests that plants somehow “hear” the sound of flowing water.
Plants have memory.
Computers have memory, yet computers are not sentient in a morally relevant sense. Thus, having memory is not sufficient for being sentient in a morally relevant sense.

There are good reasons to think that morally relevant sentience requires a central nervous system. As plants lack a central nervous system, it would follow that plants cannot be sentient in a morally relevant sense.

Without a central nervous system, there could be no integrated perception or sense of self. As a sense of self as a locus of perception, action, and experience are required to be a moral subject, a central nervous system is plausibly necessary for something to be sentient in a morally relevant sense.
Scientific research into plant nervous systems is still in its infancy. Therefore, science cannot rule out that plants are living, feeling organisms like animals.

Current research tends to rely on knowledge of the animal nervous system in order to try and prove or disprove the existence of a nervous system in plants. This cannot rule out the possibility of a very different, but no less real, plant nervous system.

Experts in the field of plant neurobiology disagree on whether plants possess the equivalent of a brain and nervous system, suggesting that there is not yet a comprehensive enough body of evidence to prove or disprove brain-like function in plants.
Given current understandings of neurology, there are good reasons to think that plants cannot feel fear, pain, and suffering in the same way as can chickens, cows, and other animals.

Sentience is not an integral component of suffering. Aversion to unpleasant stimuli is sufficient to tell us that a particular organism would not willingly choose a given condition and we can thus determine whether our behavior has moral implications.
The suggestion that one can infer willingness from aversion implies that plants have free will and intentionality, which is hard to sustain.

Plants are not regarded by the biological sciences as having an intelligence comparable to that of animals especially in respect to the ability to suffer. If this were true, one could not make an ethical distinction between harming one's neighbour and mowing his lawn.

Responding to stimulus is not sufficient to establish morally relevant sentience. All living things (even bacteria) respond to stimulus, yet not all living things are sentient in a morally relevant sense.
Plants are not the same as humans, as they are autotrophs, and thus do not require the destruction of life in their consumption practices (unless it's a carnivorous exception).
Valuing animals above plants is an anthropocentric bias based on our empathic sense to similarities that doesn't really value the life itself.

A less anthropocentric veganism would value all life in parallel to human and animal life, rendering all human behaviour immoral by virtue of the way in which we treat bacteria, plants etc. in order to sustain ourselves.
This is a non sequitur. Even conceding that veganism is anthropocentric, it does not follow that we have a right harm those with lower moral status.

Veganism is anthropocentric in that it believes in a hierarchy of sentience, with humans at the top and plants at the bottom. However, this is not a contradiction, as veganism only argues that humans should reduce suffering where possible, not that humans are no better than plants.
This is consistent with Indigenous teachings which value the lives of humans, animals, bugs, and plants equally.

No indigenous teaching can overrule the principle of minimal harm (namely, that one should seek to minimize harm). As veganism purportedly reduces harm over non-veganism, indigenous teachings cannot favor non-veganism over veganism.

The different treatment of different beings can be explained by the level of harm that can be done to that being. Sentient beings can suffer more than non-sentient beings, because they can experience pain and certain emotions (Dawkins, 2000).

Our understanding of "suffering" is also informed by how similar something is to us - the more similar to us, the more likely we are to recognize suffering when we see it. Morally consistent veganism must assume that a life can suffer whether we recognize the form of that suffering or not. As it is impossible to prove a negative, i.e. that plants *don't* suffer, then we cannot assume we have the ability to effectively limit harm.

Certain simpler forms of fauna (including many species of insects, fish and invertebrates) cannot consciously experience pain, but merely a reflexive response to physical damage that they don't have the cognitive ability to perceive as distressful. By this definition of non-violence, an ethical omnivorous diet can still rely on consumption of such animals that cannot consciously feel pain or distress.

Neuroanatomical studies have shown that many fish possess similar pain-processing receptors to higher vertebrates. It is highly possible that fish have the capacity to experience pain and suffering, albeit possibly not in the same manner that humans do.

Vegans avoid eating sentient beings. Eating some life, like plants, is necessary as it is not possible to create a complete nutritional menu from inanimate sources without the inclusion of some kind of life form.
Human existence is inherently exploitative to some life forms. Veganism is the least exploitative.

Take any society or lifestyle that consumes some animal products. Substituting those animal products with vegan alternatives, keeping all else equal, cannot make that society or lifestyle less ethical. Indeed, from an animal rights perspective, it would be far more ethical. Thus veganism is always an ethical improvement over the comparable non-vegan-ism.
It is not necessarily bad to value some lives more than others: Without species hierarchies, then it would be just as moral to kill a human as a plant, which most people would object to.

The vast majority of people (vegans and non-vegans alike) do not consider plants to be as morally significant as animals. Given the choice between cutting the stems of a dozen daisies or cutting off a dog's head, the average person will choose to kill the daisies without hesitation.
The life of an animal does not have enough value to outweigh the benefits of killing and consuming them.
One cow makes roughly 2500 dollars worth in beef alone, set aside the benefit from its skin and bones.
The well-being of humans and the well-being of animals are not mutually exclusive.

Humans are not inherently better than other animals (an idea propped up by religion: Genesis 1:26 Genesis 1:27), only evidently more cruel, subjecting animals to confinement from birth, mutilation, and imbalanced diet to manipulate growth. These aren't practiced by carnivorous animals in nature.

Religion shows otherwise, that eating animals makes humans worse off (as we are not above them), not better. "Be not among drunkards or among gluttonous eaters of meat, for the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and slumber will clothe them with rags" Proverbs 23:20-21.
To be legitimate, rights should be based on a real understanding of the thing to which they are given. Since many humans cannot empathise with animals, it cannot be said that they have rights.
Animal rights should not be sacrificed just because of our own ignorance. Humans should become better people.

Even if humans lack the empathy needed to co-exist with animals right now, they could be taught to empathize at a high enough level to never need to get to a point where the lack of it comes at the cost to animal rights.
Many humans also cannot empathise with other humans, which does in no way mean that some humans don't deserve rights.
We should strive to avoid killing animals and allow them a right to live, but is impractical to achieve those ideals in their entirety in reality.
People could accidentally kill animals easily without noticing it, like insects, or intentionally to prevent themselves from getting harmed (like animals carrying illnesses to not get sick).
Killing insects accidentally is not immoral, just as accidental manslaughter is not immoral, inasmuch as one cannot choose not to do it.
Killing cows and pigs is more immoral than killing insects.

Killing invading animals that pose some sort of threat or risk to you may be killed because they pose some threat or risk to you. Animals that do not pose some sort of threat or risk need not be killed.
Veganism does not preclude one's right to self-defence.
Suffering is to some extent unavoidable because it is impossible to prevent, at least without violating another's rights.
Rights are artificial constructs created to order human behavior and, as such, animals cannot have innate, individual rights.
To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.
Animals are not moral actors and as such their abuse, exploitation and life are not subject to a question of morals.
Plants are identical to animals in their inability to make moral decisions, yet humans must eat to survive.
The inability to make moral decisions does not render plants and animals morally equivalent.
Morality is an evolutionary by-product of human intellect. Most animals do not have comparative intellect.

Animals need not be moral actors, but only moral subjects. That is, morals need not apply to what an animal does, but only to what others do to the animals. As animals are moral subjects, what humans do to animals is morally relevant and important.

Babies are not moral actors, but they are moral subjects. It is immoral to harm babies. However, as babies do not and cannot know any better, if a baby were to cause harm, the baby would not be acting immorally. Animals are similar to babies in this respect.

People who are asleep or in temporary comas are not moral actors, as they cannot act. Yet it is immoral to do harm to a person who is asleep or in a temporary coma as they are still moral subjects. The same applies to animals.
No laws have been enacted to protect these rights for animals either so no legal system is being undermined by this.
There are many laws that protect the rights of animals (e.g. not to be abused).
Animals' lack of rights does not mean they shouldn't have the right to not to be exploited.
In the past humans have failed to grant other groups of humans rights, we may be as wrong now about not granting rights to animals as we were then.
When most humans eat animals they do not consider the death that was required for their meal. If people had to consider the actual consequences of their diet far more would be vegan.
This claim makes an assumption that is certainly false as many people eat the animals they themselves kill.
Even if some people are prepared to kill the animals they eat, it doesn't mean most people are.
Only 35% of hunters consider meat being the (main?) reason for hunting according to Responsive Management ("Motivations behind hunting")
The idea that we should stop doing things on the basis of them being distasteful would have disastrous consequences for human civilization.
Jobs like sewage processing and high-rise building construction, which many wouldn't dare perform, are essential to human civilization.
The fact that something minimizes suffering does not entail that that thing is morally correct.
Mass extinction, in preventing suffering from being experienced, minimizes suffering, and yet it seems not to be morally correct.

The important and neglected concept is needless suffering rather than any suffering. Some suffering happens that could be avoided, and such suffering is always immoral. Given that any scenario could be morally improved by eliminating needless suffering, it is moral to minimize needless suffering.
With ethical farming practices, one can be vegetarian and still prevent needless harm and death of animals too. One doesn't need to go vegan for that to occur.
Despite many believing its goods are merely 'by-products', the dairy industry can be as cruel - if not worse - than the meat industry.
Dairy cows are often artificially impregnated in order to ensure a continuous supply of milk from the cows.
Some dairy cows are not adequately treated (due to saving costs or bad practice), which creates antibiotic resistance in the herd.
Dairy cows regularly get infections, such as mastitis, from their treatment on dairy farms.
This is in addition to the cruelty of cows being sick because farms create the environment that cause such infections.
Issues with antibiotic resistance aren't exclusive to dairy farms, as it happens with growing crops (like apples) too.
The male calves, considered 'waste', are killed, as they can't produce milk, which is cruel.
Calves are removed from the mothers at birth in the dairy industry, which is cruel to both calf and mother.
Long-term studies found no evidence that calves suffer behaviourally or developmentally when separated from their mothers.
With vegetarianism, animals still suffer needlessly, even if it does do a lot of prevention in reducing it, which is why veganism is the way to go.
By not being vegan (instead of vegetarian), people still support the needless death of animals.
Male chicks are not beneficial to the industry (they can't lay eggs), so most of them are killed, sometimes immediately after birth.

This wouldn't need to happen if male chicks are given to chicken farms to raise them for meat. Then chicken farms don't need to raise their own chickens for meat, thus saving lives without needing to go vegan.

To produce milk a cow is impregnated by force, made to carry young for 9 months, and their babies are taken away at birth. If male he is killed for veal, if female the cycle repeats. The cow goes through this process over and over until she is "spent" (usually only a few years as opposed to a long 20 year life) and then sent to slaughter.
Stating that there are other diets that reduce animal suffering doesn't refute this, but instead it affirms the consequent (a formal logical fallacy).
Factory farms make up a majority of the farming industry in the US and Canada.
Ethical farming practices are too rare for most people to avoid the unnecessary death and suffering of animals without being (mostly) vegan.

It's not possible to make sure ethical practices always or ever exist, because there's no way to get permission from an animal before exploiting them or verify an animal is taken care of even when it's no longer profitable to (as there's an incentive not to).
Ethical vegetarianism is not feasible in a corporate fashion. Corporations cannot be trusted to uphold the rights of animals when their main motive is profit.
Veganism exploits and kills more animals than it saves.
In a vegan world, many farmed animals would either live in worse conditions or never get the chance to live at all.
Farmed animal species benefit from selective breeding.
Animal farming is a mutualistic relationship that has led to chickens and cows being the most successful birds and non-human mammals on Earth.
Humans realize which genes and traits keep an animal alive and which do not. Without humans, the livestock's evolutionary line might not be here today.
Since we have control over the reproductive processes of animals, then we can modify them to help them survive in conditions they never could without us.

This evolutionary line is optimized (p.1) for human needs, not for the animals', for example chickens that can't support their own body weight because of their disproportionately large chests (due to high demand for chicken breast). We are not doing them a favor.
The relationship that has been created between humans and some species of animals has come at a cost to other animals.
Non-livestock animals die or go extinct just to keep the few remaining livestock species alive rather than vice versa.
Animal farming is predation, which is less beneficial for the species.
For some animals, such as deer in the UK, humans do act as the top predator and are needed to control numbers.
The top predator is always present in the animal kingdom, in accordance with the ecosystem. Humans have built systems outside of ecosystem, so outside of natural predators.
A farmer is a predator that both breeds and kills you, which is not comparable to a predator killing already existing animals in the wild for food, for its survival.
Farming is not normal predatory behaviour because it exceeds and replaces natural predator activity.
The longer animals are around humans, the more they lose their naturally evolved traits.
If animals keep their features, humans can learn from their uniqueness. If changed, that may not happen.
The human-animal relationship seen in animal agriculture today is parasitism at the least and parasitoidism at its worst (1).
Selective breeding methods, which are inherent to animal farming, are immoral.
Determining what's 'good' for other animals is like playing god with them. This isn't our role, so we shouldn't be doing it.
Selective breeding methods negatively impact the welfare of farm animals.

Artificial selection for animal survival is only short-term. The further we go the more the animal and their survive gets bred out of their own existence (as helping them is less about the animal and more for people), as seen with disappearing 'heritage' breeds along with ideas for veganism and cultured meat. So leaving animals alone to survive is best for them at this point.

Most domestic animals cannot breed on their own naturally, because they're bred for their food products, not reproduction. So the population would die out in a few decades once their lives are over without artificial insemination to prop it up.

The breeds humans "created" are optimized for putting on weight quickly (so much so that many of them have severe mobility issues) and have many of their natural instincts removed. Most of them would not stand a chance in the wild so it would not make sense to keep them around if we decided not to eat meat anymore.
Livestock have their physical needs met by farmers.
Livestock recieve shelter and protection from predators.
A farmed animal does not have to live in constant fear of predation as it does in the wild.

This is true, because farms try to remove that fear. The process involves coaxing farm animals to not worry or not showing them their death until the end, if at all (leading the animals to believe that people are just raising and not killing them).

There is lots of footage around that demonstrates how the killing is not always clean and painless. Animals fighting back, animals being insufficiently stunned and noticing how they're being lowered into a scalding tub alive, pigs who are suffocated in CO2 chambers and go into panic as they realize they're not able to breathe. The methods are far from perfect.

Farm animals do live in fear, they just have been bred to not react to their predation. Domestic animals have aggression and other genetic traits taken out of them to prevent them from struggle and fighting their predators (a.k.a. humans).

While animals might not be aggressive towards humans, their reaction to the conditions of being raised and bred by humans is still aggression and nervousness. That's why chickens get their claws and beaks cut off, so they don't start attacking each other.

Farming practices should not be described as "protecting" animals and "taking care of offspring" when it inevitably leads to the death of the animals and their offspring for the financial gain of the producer.
Livestock recieve healthcare.
Ethical farming exists, that treats animals extremely well and puts extra emphasis on animal dignity.

The non-industrialized production and use of dairy products (milk and eggs) is not innately exploitative or unethical because domesticated animals do not suffer, but are are rather fed, nurtured, and protected by the humans that raise them in a mutually beneficial process.

If we swap the highly optimized conventional animal agriculture (which relies on animals being treated like commodities in order to maximize profits) for non-exploitative, "symbiotic" ways of raising and keeping animals, we would have to live on mostly vegan diets anyway, since these methods of obtaining animal products have much lower yields and take up even more resources.

Just because it might be possible, in theory, to raise animals ethically, does not mean it is ethical to consume animal products right now, as we are far away from widespread implementation of these "humane" practices.

All animals are eventually killed, whether by humans or other animals or nature. Meat producers usually want animals to die quickly to prevent pain-associated chemicals from forming, as they spoil the meat. Thus, they use the most humane means possible.
A farmed animal can be provided with a life that is worth living. Free-range farming with an enhanced environment to stimulate the animals is possible, so that the animals' life is worth living.

Free-range is an elastic term, meaning that the definition is arbitrary and can be changed. Likely free-range will not be much better or more ethical than conventional farming (if we don't account for the environment).

We are in no position to decide whether an animal's life has been "good enough already" for it to be killed as we can't measure happiness. This highly subjective criteria of happiness is not sufficient for deciding when to end an animal's life until we have a better understanding of how and what animals feel.

We wouldn't kill a dog that had a happy childhood at two years of age just because that happiness ought to suffice for a lifetime. We instead try to maximize the amount of happy years our pets can spend on this planet. We don't do this with livestock, we set an arbitrary limit on how much happiness they deserve so that it fits our needs (eating them).
It is impossible to know whether free farmed animals' lives are worth living as this value judgement is highly subjective and likely biased by our own anthropocentric, predatory value systems.
Animals wanting to be meat goes against biology. Biologically, animals want to survive and reproduce, not be some predator's meal.

If we allow animals to live long and fulfilled lives before eating them, raising and killing them for food would be a lot less economically feasible, leading to a major drop in the availability of animal products (or extremely increased prices), which would in turn lead to an almost-vegan diet anyways.
Humane farming is only marginally better than traditional animal agriculture, yet notoriously hard to implement because of backlash from the industry and consumers who fear rising prices.

The fraction of the lifespan of farm animals compared to their maximum lifespan in captivity is much smaller than the lifespan of wild animals compared to their lifespan in captivity, e.g. the red deer lives 10 years in the wild and 20 in captivity (Red deer), which result in a fraction of 0.5. For dairy cows this fraction is ~0.25 and for chickens raised for meat 0.02 (hsi.org.au).

The second source (the one about actual livestock animal) is not a scientific peer reviewed research, but a simple infographics. Secondly, it talks about "expected" life expectancy (meaning how long can the body hold ideally), not the realistic one. Between sickness, predators, natural agents and all of the sorts, they would not realistically live as long. In nature being elder is rare, humanity is exceptional. Furthermore, most mammals live longer, healthier, and less stressed in captivity.

Even though domesticated dogs do have a better life being cared for by humans than they would have as wolves in the wild, you wouldn't advocate killing dogs in their early adolescence to be eaten like cows or pigs are. Caring for an animal doesn't automatically make it morally permissible to kill it, it is perfectly possible and beneficial to both parties to let the animal live, as is the case with pets.
There's no such thing as ethical killing. If animals are taken care only for the purpose of killing them that is ethically wrong when there is an alternative.
Domesticated animals, livestock and other animals that depend on humans for feed and would otherwise starve to death.
If all humans became vegan, then all the animals on farms would be killed anyway as no-one is going to pay to look after them.

Most of the animals dependent on humans are in that situation because humans put them in it. When all humans will be vegan there won't be any more animals bred for farms. All animals dependent on humans should be prevented from breeding.

The number of domesticated animals would gradually but drastically diminish (probably of several orders of magnitude) as the practice of forced, artificial reproduction would be dismissed; the remaining "domesticated" animals would be taken care of by their owners.
Farmed animals are still deprived of freedom as their lives remain controlled by farmers.

Putting animals in a catch-22, where they lose either way (having no life, or have a bad life and dying early) are equally terrible and not worth it. Neither are good options nor real choices, as the chance for a good life is too small. The best option is a good, long life with a natural, uninfluenced death if we choose to breed them, not a short life.
It is better for farmed animals to never get the chance to live at all.
Breeding more farmed animals comes at the sacrifice of others, including both animals and humans.
Industrial farming uses massive amounts of resources and contributes to climate change, which could lead to a mass extinction event.

Computer modelling indicates that the United States could support the largest human population on domestic production if everybody followed a lacto-ovo vegetarian diet, surpassing the carrying capacity of veganism.

Farming benefits from including temporary grass leys in the rotation, and the way to get the most return in useable protein from this grass is through dairy (beef is another ballgame with abysmal amounts of protein/hectare produced).

While the vegetarian diet can maximize the use of all available land in the US, it is not necessary to use up every inch of land if you don't need it in order to sustain the population. This is like saying a school bus is better suited for transporting a family of six than a minivan.

Many areas that can only be used as grazing land are barren because they have been exploited and overworked by human agriculture. Allowing these areas to be taken over by natural plants and forests again would benefit soil quality and biodiversity, there is no need to put animals on them for grazing.
Creating more animals for the meat and dairy industry adds more animals into a world already struggling to provide for its existing population.
Sustainable farming practices do not have these problems. This fails as a criticism of farming as a whole.
A life in a factory farm is worse than no life at all.

Some mushrooms and plants (like some figs) are carnivorous and might be unknowingly consumed by vegans (because they're too small, go unnoticed, etc.) just because the end product is a vegan food item.
People sometimes use animals for fertilizer, such as fish.
There are other available sources of fertilizer, e.g. plant-matter compost.
Many animals are killed in the production of plant-based food, including rabbits, mice, hamsters and other rodents, ground-nesting birds, deer fawn, snakes, etc.
Vegan agriculture most likely will not stop its heavy use of pesticides, insecticides, and more animal-killing chemicals, because they make vegan products viable for consumer markets.

Vegan food production, with these chemicals, may cause more net deaths to the ecosystem (especially wildlife) in an open loop compared to buying farmed natural predators (like larger insects, such as praying mantises and ladybugs, to eat the smaller insects, like aphids).

Buying farmed insects as natural pesticides decreases the death toll (as insects cannot breed as easily) as well as create a closed loop (the insects eat other ones instead of just dying, so their bodily material goes back to the environment through the circle-of-life).

As the article mentions, such pesticides cause more harm than the target pest, affecting other animals and possibly humans. This causes a lot of damage for animals that people do not even think of when envisioning vegan food.
Farmers may take land away from wildlife to farm crops, which is why some species become threatened. One crop of particular concern is palm oil.

Palm oil farmers are destroying the habitats of many wildlife species, thereby contributing to animal suffering. Therefore, this technically vegan crop violates the vegan principle of not mistreating animals for food.
Even the greenhouse gases rising from the deforestation contribute to animal suffering.
The Vegan Society is very critical toward the use of palm oil, so many vegans avoid using it.
Palm oil is primarily used as fuels, animal feed and in non-vegan foods and products. Palm oil is not a vegan issue, but a human issue.
The public will not likely see how their food is made, thus making regulation less likely upon the process than the final consumer product.
For raising animals, you need plants and while producing this you also kill the mice and snakes that live there.
Feeding animals and then eating those animals requires more crops than simply eating plants directly, which results in more mice, hares, snakes, insects etc. being killed.
The accidental deaths from growing and harvesting plants are ethically different to the intentional deaths caused by slaughtering animals for food.
Pesticides and insecticides are designed to be as deadly as possible. They are truly WMDs of agriculture and their killing is just as far from "accidental".
Unfortunately, the outcome is the same for those animals.

This isn't a case against veganism, but rather against harmful methods of growing crops. If crops are grown in a way that doesn't kill animals (indoor, hydroponic farming; cultured plant cells, like cultured meat; etc.) or if the crops that are most detrimental to local fauna are avoided, then this issue is negated.
Insects, such as bees and bumblebees, are used by the agriculture industry to grow crops.

Bees would pollinate many plants regardless of whether they are industrially grown by farmers, or exist in the wild. Therefore the role of pollination in the agriculture industry does not constitute exploitation.

Quantity is not a relevant argument in relation to the virtue of the principles, considering that the larger number results from intentionally protecting the plants from pest insects, and that the other source is the result of mass-scale economy prioritisation and always stands in relation to the crop-type. Since defending yourself (and the extended necessities) are not related to animal exploitation, they don't apply to veganism.
Depending on how field deaths are defined and quantified, some research on plant agriculture contests that plant agriculture kills more animals it saves (p. 22).
A balanced, responsible, ethical and sustainable agriculture where no animal is killed exists.
If people grow crops indoors hydroponically or aeroponically plus vertically, then they can avoid killing most, if any, animals.

Agriculture on the scale needed to feed entire countries is not possible without doing it in the open air, where any wild animal and countless insects can wander into the cultivated area and be effectively hidden and, subsequently, killed during the farming process. Indeed, pollination requires animals as part of the process.

Humans have a moral obligation to be responsible for what we eat. So even though we can choose any food we want to eat, we need to also act within our principles to do the right thing within our choices.

It is speciesist to grant humans the right to eat meat on grounds of their enjoyment or freedom when raising cattle for human consumption necessitates depriving these animals of the same rights to freedom and enjoyment.

If a higher developed, more intelligent species were to invade our planet and develop a taste for human flesh, no human would advertise the invaders' rights to eat what they want. We would want them to recognize our will to live and find something else to eat. If we put ourselves above animals because of our higher intellect, that intellect also compels us to treat those who are dependent on us with their best interests in mind.
Humans shouldn't be treated differently (i.e. with a double-standard) than other animals, as humans are animals too and tend to eat other animals.
The double standard for humans to not be able to eat meat, but animals can is a biased opinion; the self-hate for one's species should not be a contribution towards humanity.

There is a difference between humans and other carnivores and omnivores, as humans act like an invasive species, but for all ecosystems. In fact, we're considered "the most dangerous" of them all. So we should be treated differently, because we act differently, worse than any other animal in existence.
Speciesism is a naturally occurring phenomenon.
Complex cognitive differences in how humans think and experience emotions mean that it is natural for us to perceive ourselves as superior to other animals.

Speciesism is grounded in genetic proximity and is rejected on the same grounds that we reject Nazi-Germany, racism, and genocide. Genocidal tendencies are "natural" in evolution but morally reprehensible nonetheless.

Humans have a responsibility for managing the food chain/web through what we eat, due to our privileged position at the top of it. Instead of just managing one ecosystem to keep it healthy, we would need to achieve that for the entire world's environment altogether.
Vegan principles would bring benefits to human society.
Veganism tends to support the rights of humans, as well as benefiting animals.
It's egalitarian in letting everyone start out equally in life with the same diet.
Even if all humans were vegan, it does not follow that the vegan diets of the rich and poor would be equal in quality, variety, or reliability.

Vegan farming pushes for plants grown around the world, which can actually push people off native land taken for farming or raise prices of foods in other countries to fulfill the Western diet. Veganism that isn't locally grown supports Western colonialism of poor agricultural industries.
Meat industry workers and their communities suffer.
Safety standards in the meat industry are poor.
Both abattoir workers and meat packing employees are at a concerningly high risk of injury.
The meatpacking industry is particularly dangerous.
Even though the numbers are low, meatpacking is still a pretty dangerous industry due to under-reporting.
Safety standards can be raised and enforced. Banning something outright because the standards are currently lax is throwing the baby out with the bathwater.
Safety standards differ between countries, some may be better than the United States (which the article above discusses).

With the COVID-19 outbreak impacting meat plants disproportionately more, health inspectors inspecting them possibly contract the coronavirus and have fatalities from their inspections from close contact with it there.
Slaughterhouse employees report that the work severely affects their emotional and mental health.
Slaughterhouses create and increase PTSD in their workers.
Having to kill hundreds of animals amounts to repetitive trauma. This type of trauma can lead to a specific type of PTSD known as complex PTSD, which is also observed in child abuse victims.

Many slaughterhouse workers experience PTSD symptoms: including a lack of empathy and mental disturbances, which have been observed in higher rates of criminals. This might explain why we see higher criminality rates in communities surrounding slaughterhouses.

Many slaughterhouse employees describe the emotional toll of having to kill animals that they do not want to harm, and may even have connected with. As a result, they are forced to stop caring completely to cope with the emotional dissonance of their job.
It is possible to eat meat that does not come from a slaughterhouse.
This is a small proportion of the meat consumed.
Vegan food production often treats its workers unethically.
Many popular vegan crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as low pay.

Most crops (especially in richer areas on the globe) are produced for animal feed. Changing to a plant-based diet would mean that less farmers would be needed to produce crops, thus less farmers needs to be checked on employer welfare standards with the same amount of resources.
The cultivation and production of cashews requires workers to come into contact with harmful toxins, causing significant health problems.

Vegan consumers who do not grow their own vegan food often put more money in the pockets of corporate crop farms such as Monsanto and Chiquita (formerly the United Fruit Company), who interfere with the lives of developing world indigenous farmers by patenting their crops and abusing labour rights.
These consumers can be informed that these companies go against veganism by exploiting and harming sentient creatures for personal gain, and avoid these companies.
Even with the knowledge that these companies are unethical, it is difficult to avoid buying from them.

There are no exclusively vegan crops. Food and products consumed by vegans are also eaten/used by non-vegans directly, and indirectly via the livestock they consume. The problem tracks back to the production industry, not veganism itself.
Once people go vegan, they may want to reduce their negative social impact by buying local foods or growing their own.
Local and growing food industries might grow when everyone goes vegan, which will make it easier to avoid worker exploitation.
Most western Europeans consume food from all around the world. This is not vegan related. Local and ethical is possible with vegan as well.
Veganism promotes empathy.
If we look at the moral arc of history, the consistent theme is an ever-expanding circle of empathy as societies progress. Expanding the circle to include animals represents continued moral progress.
In relatively recent history, we have seen the circle expand from the abolishment of slavery to the civil rights movement, to gay rights.
During this period there has also been a consistent pattern of increasing concern for animals and their rights.
The ever-expanding circle empathy is descriptive not prescriptive. Moving past what is currently being practiced must be justified in its own right.

Teaching children empathy for animals will likely create a more empathetic and kinder society. There is a strong correlation between cruel behavior toward animals and lack of empathy for human beings.
Some aspects of veganism involve racism. Racism could potentially get worse, through veganism, if implemented fully.
Veganism is typically depicted using white, affluent individuals despite its non-white roots.
The foods most associated with vegan meals originated in communities of color.

In countries where the majority of the population is white, it is reasonable that a certain proportion of the depiction is of white people. The lack of representation of POC is a general problem of those countries that is not caused by, but rather reflected in veganism (among other domains).

The most fundamental and influential organisations behind veganism like PETA or Seventh-day Adventist Church are founded and run by white and affluent individuals, with non-white roots nowhere to be found.
Veganism is primarily a first world phenomenon, with vegans in Asia, Africa, Australia or South America constituting 1 percent of population or less.
Advertisements of veganism can often involve problematic comparisons to the suffering undergone by minority communities.

Many pro-vegan publications and media productions have been criticised for problematically comparing the suffering of animals in the food industry to the plight of Jewish prisoners during the holocaust.
PETA released an advertisement that compared the poultry industry to the Holocaust.
The controversial film 'Earthlings' compares our treatment of animals to the Nazis' treatment of Jews during the Second World War.
It is common for pro-vegan media to compare animal use to slavery.
PETA released an advertisement in which cartoon animals took the knee and called for the end of speciesism.
These comparisons are only problematic when we misconstrue them as equating the value of human life with animal life, when really they're comparing our moral considerations of humans versus animals.
In a world in which everyone is vegan, advertisements for veganism would be redundant and thus not occur.
Being encouraged to drink milk is racist since it overlooks the fact that many ethnic minority groups are lactose intolerant.
Many vegan companies pro-actively tackle racism, such as Beyond Meat and Miyoko's.
Human society benefits from domestic animals.
A vegan society would tend to replace animals with technology, thus leading humanity further in its disconnection to nature and life.
Academic and laboratory research often relies on animal testing and experimentation. Many academics, scientists, and industries would lose grants, funding, and jobs if everyone went vegan.
The pharmaceutical industry would not exist right now without animal testing, as it is part of drug research process.
The testing itself could still take place on human volunteers.
In the primary stages of drug research, the risk to human health may be so high that even using volunteers would be unethical. This is why animals are tested on prior to human trials.
If people stay healthy through participating in a vegan diet, then they could avoid consuming medications made from animal products or involved animals in their research and testing.

While veganism strives to reduce animal suffering wherever possible, it would be a gradual development and not an overnight shock. We can start with food, where we already have many satisfactory alternatives, and worry about animal testing when we have more efficient ways (e.g. better computer models) for testing in biology.
There are an increasing number of alternatives to animal testing, which also require academic input. Funds and grants would likely be diverted to these in the event that animals testing ceased.
Domestic animals have a positive impact on physical and mental health of humans.
Pets have a positive impact on the emotional development of children (p. 25).
For thousands of years, humans have been breeding species, selecting them to respond to specific needs and provide useful benefits. If we stopped breeding them at all, we would lose those benefits.
Domestic animals provide mechanical aid, such as transportation of humans and goods, ploughing, grass maintenance, etc.
Some domestic animals can increase security by surveilling.
Domestic animals can be trained to work with the police or rescuers.
Domestic animals can be used in therapy.
Not all people share the same ethical principles, so a vegan lifestyle doesn't necessarily bring benefits to all humans.
Some specific methods of animal slaughter are considered perfectly ethical in some religions and cultures.
Religious procedures like halal and tayyib are intended to protect an animal's spirit, ensuring they are treated with dignity.
Just because something is a cultural practice or deeply believed doesn't make it right or ethical. Appeal to tradition is a logical fallacy.
Tradition is superseded by logic and scientific discovery.

The argument is not that tradition makes veganism not right or unethical, it is that some religions, cultures, and traditions are fundamentally against it, and it is not morally right to force these religions, cultures, and traditions to change.
Many vegan staples are imported, and imported foods can be ethically problematic.
Foods imported could have negative associations, such as 'blood avocados' and their relations to drug trafficking.
Nothing suggests that vegans eat more imported foods than non-vegans.
Killing animals for food is natural, and so not inherently unethical or morally blameworthy.
Humans are just another type of animal; we are only as morally obliged not to kill other species as they are morally obliged not to kill each other.
Most of the animals killed for food, cows, pigs, chickens, do not usually kill humans. By the principle of reciprocity, we should therefore not kill them either.
The distinction of human vs. non-human animal is arbitrary. We could just as well draw the line between Europeans|Africans, and use this distinction to justifiably kill the other.

If humans and animals exist on the same moral plane, then humans are simply another part of the natural food web with no more moral responsibility regarding predator/prey relationships than any other animal.
If something being natural for all predators means it cannot be immoral, then killing out of greed and envy cannot be immoral, as it too is natural. Yet killing out of greed and envy is immoral.
Early modern humans were more prey than predator then, evolving instincts to repulse animals (like phobias, fight-or-flight, patternicity, and anxiety), not those to kill them.

Even our most common instinct of animal-killing, intraspecies predation (killing and eating humans, which are animals), is frowned upon. In fact, it is so natural, some humans are genetically resistant to cannibalism-related diseases, like prions.
If certain people evolved to be cannibals, that proves that predation is in fact a natural instinct in humans.

Our bodies match our lack of predatory instincts and never really evolved them, because we outsourced our hunting capabilities to tools instead of our bodies (except using our minds to hunt). Without tools, getting meat would be very difficult, whereas it would be no issue for a carnivore or omnivore. They even started to be used around when humans started eating meat.

Even when humans take on the role of being a predator, they act differently than most real predators by being a 'super-predator'. The behavior is so irregular, it is even unsustainable and devastates ecosystems. Humans are not meant to be predators and kill animals, our poor judgment and behavior illustrates it is not a natural instinct, even for nature.
Contrary to popular assumptions, there is evidence that humans have specific hunting traits, and often express a natural hunting instinct.
The 'thrilling' effect of hunting has been replicated by hunting-based video games and sport (rather than subsistence) hunting, such as safari hunting and catch-and-release fishing.
Just because we have these skills doesn't automatically mean we should be using them, as that's a rights to ought fallacy.
It isn't natural to want to kill, but killing is necessitated by the desire for food, which is greater than the repulsion to killing.
Instinctive behavior becomes immoral and unethical when we know better, as at that point we can choose.
People's current animal-killing desire is unnatural and rare, associated with sociopaths, and stems from trauma in life, not at birth, as we have choices now not to kill animals for food.
Killing animals causes habitual progression that makes humans immoral and more violent.
Just because something is natural does not mean that it is good. This is the 'appeal to nature' fallacy.
Worldwide veganism would improve public health.
Veganism can bring down healthcare costs.

Healthcare costs the US almost $3.5 trillion with 85% of that going to preventable chronic diseases like heart disease and type 2 diabetes. The savings (about $3 trillion) would be more than enough to transition the world to a vegan diet.
If vegans live longer, this could cause healthcare costs to rise. Therefore, it would just be a prolonged zero-sum game.

Red meats are linked to certain types of cancers which become very costly from a medical standpoint. According to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), cancer related treatment cost the U.S. $80.2 billion in 2015 alone.
Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of communicable diseases.
Vegans are less likely to contract and then spread toxoplasmosis, a parasite found in pets or undercooked meat.

While human to human infection is not common, toxoplasmosis can be passed by affected pregnant women to their baby or, rarely, can be transmitted via a contaminated blood transfusion or organ donation.
Vegans are more likely to contract toxoplasmosis. They are more likely to encounter vegetables that have grown where cat faeces might also be deposited, such as in gardens and smaller plots.
The raising and selling of livestock as meat spreads disease.
A vegan society would reduce the chances of zoonotic diseases transferring between animals and humans.
The largest outbreaks are linked to poor conditions in markets and factory farms. Veganism can limit the number of outbreaks, and in turn, the number of cases/deaths from these diseases worldwide.
The 2020-2021 coronavirus pandemic in humans is largely attributed to the live sale of animals in a wet market.
The link to a food-animal source for COVID-19 (i.e. a Wuhan wet market) is inconclusive and full scientific investigation has only just begun.
Every major pandemic (and purportedly the bubonic plague) either have confirmed or suspected links to animal-keeping, as the viruses are zoonotic.
Being vegan reduces the risk of catching diseases from raising livestock, such as swine flu.
Livestock cause over half of all deaths from food-borne illnesses (see Table 3).
Vegans are less likely to come into contact with foodborne illnesses like pathogenic E. Coli, often found in animal products.
Plant-based agriculture can also spread diseases.
The spread of disease in animals is more likely to pass to humans than disease in plant crops due to genetic and biochemical similarities.
While this may be true the resistance occurs in organisms which are not a direct threat to humans, whereas animal pathogens can jump to humans carrying with them their resistances.
Even food-borne illnesses in crops come from livestock through water and soil contamination.
The way meat is produced promotes antibiotic resistance. Going vegan will drastically lower the chances of getting ill from antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
80% of antibiotics sold go to animal agriculture, with most (70%) of them also used by humans. Thus, livestock increases the likelihood of antibiotic resistance to diseases people get.
Some chickens are not given any antibiotics.
Wildlife may still be a source of food-borne illnesses in vegan food.
The most effective way to prevent communicable diseases in humans is through the practice of good hygiene and food safety education (p. 754).
Veganism could help eradicate world hunger.
If the crops grown for animals were instead grown for humans, 70% more calories would be available for human consumption – enough to sustain 10 billion people.
More than 800 million people in the world are starving. Livestock feed grain could feed them all alone and still have some left over.

The crops are located right where the impoverished growers are, which cuts out transportation costs to eat them, making it really affordable for growers to afford the food compared to expensive, distant animal products.

Even in developed countries, the farmworkers cannot afford or want to eat the vegan crops they grow. So just because the food won't go to livestock anymore, doesn't automatically make mean it'll solve world hunger.
Animals are primarily fed on crop co-products, residue and plants that humans cannot eat.
Said co-products can also be used as fertilisers, thus breaking the need for more animals or oil-based fertilisers.
Raising animals for human consumption requires more crops and farmland than not using animals.
According to pyramid of biomass, it takes 10x the amount of food for animals to consume than it creates for humans (for example, 200kg of feed makes 20kg of meat).

The pyramid of biomass makes sense, as eating an animal takes three extra, measurable steps: Firstly, the plants' chemical energy has been digested into usable form. Secondly, some energy is used by the animal. Finally, the energy is transformed/stored within the animal (which we would then eat).
It is possible to cultivate 15 times more protein on any given area of land with soybeans rather than grazing cows.

A vegan diet is the most efficient way to use land. A vegan requires 1/6th of an acre for a year of food, a vegetarian needs three times that much, and a meat eater needs 18-fold more land than a vegan.
World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitics.
Starvation happens because the people can either not pay for that food or through war or disaster it is not reaching the local communities. A vegan society will not change those reasons.
Veganism will not solve hunger, because if there are no paying customers for the grain that is grown for livestock, then farmers will not grow it, or if they have it, give it to those in need.
World hunger has always existed, as it can be caused by extreme weather changes, or natural disasters.
Arbitrarily discarded fruit and vegetables, such as the billions of pounds of ugly produce, could feed hundreds of thousands of people worldwide.
Vegan foods can be more readily and more cheaply preserved for longer.
Whole, minimally-processed vegan foods require less refrigeration than animal products, which spoil quickly. This makes vegan food cheaper and more feasible for less privileged individuals/societies.
Many vegan foods do not require freezing or canning and have a shelf life of 2 years or longer.
Freezing, canning, even drying meat increases their shelf life too. Food waste can be reduced, no matter what the food product is, animal or non-animal.
Manure-based fertilizers benefit agriculture. Reducing livestock numbers will make agriculture more difficult and costly.
The eradication of world hunger must include providing a reliably balanced and sufficient diet. Veganism does not do this.
A number of essential vitamins are extremely difficult to obtain through a strictly vegan diet.
Vegan diets are at an increased risk of B12 deficiency among other vitamin deficiencies.
There is a study that shows that low Vitamin B12 levels during pregnancy set up a worse life (more prone to drugs) for their progeny.
The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics warns about the risk of vitamin B12 deficiencies in vegans. While these can be safely gained from supplements, they are at greater risk.
Without adequate Vitamin B12 supplements on a vegan diet, people can get pernicious anemia.

Pernicious anemia could happen to those with medical and genetic risk factors (vegans are only a small %). They need to take Vitamin B12 shots, regardless of where the B12 comes from in the diet if their digestive system cannot absorb B12 anymore.
B12 deficiency alone can lead to sensory neuropathy and possible permanent neurological damage if untreated. Vegan diets need to be carefully structured or supplemented with vitamins.
Without taking synthetically produced goods it is almost impossible to obtain sufficient Vitamin B12 on a vegan diet.
A bioavailable version of Vitamin B12 (the main vitamin that vegans supplement) is found in one plant so far: duckweed.
As Vitamin B12 is found in soil, especially with plant roots, people could get the vitamin by eating roots without washing them thoroughly.

Meat contains the essential vitamin B12, yet this B12 is often supplemented into the animal's food. Therefore when supplementing B12 yourself and eating healthy, 'intermediary' meat' becomes obsolete.
B12 deficiency is not an issue for informed vegans. Recent research results suggest that no significant vitamins or minerals deficiencies affect the vegan population compared to non vegans.
Vitamin B12 deficiencies are sometimes caused by industrialization. In nature, people do not need to take in as much B12, so it is less of an issue.

Because of industrialization, it might be harder to get Vitamin B12 in nature than in the past. Survival without eating meat would be difficult if people are near resource-exploited or -depleted areas.
Vitamin B12 is naturally made by bacteria, not animals. For this reason, vegan B12 supplements can be produced easily and cheaply.

Vitamin B12 deficiency takes many years to develop, due to recycling and storage in the liver. As most survival situations are much shorter than this, a plant-based diet is ample for survival way before any meat is needed.
39% of the general population may be in the low normal and deficient B12 blood level range. There is no significant difference between those who ate meat and those who did not.
A vegan diet may worsen magnesium and vitamin A deficiencies currently experienced by 1 in 4 US children.
Vitamin D3 is rarely found in plants and will be inadequate in a vegan diet unless supplemented.
D3 is inadequate in vegan diets, that is why meat is a good source of D3 (the livestock gets its source from microbes that produce it).

All diets are poor in vitamin D3: " The paradox with ‘vitamin D’ is that diet per se is usually poor in vitamin D" (Norman, 2001). "The most well-known source of vitamin D is via synthesis in the skin induced by sun exposure." ncbi.nlm.nih.gov
There are multiple plant-based sources of Vitamin D3 (pp. 15-16).
Vegan vitamin D3 supplements are sourced from lichens. They are especially beneficial for vegans who stay too long indoors.
People produce their own Vitamin D from the sun (1, 2, 3) and do not need supplementation with this method.
This source prevents overdosing on Vitamin D (as seen in the third article), as the body produces only what it needs.
Animal products can lack sufficient amounts of essential nutrients, such as Vitamin C.

Omnivores can eat any sources, so they do not worry about deficiencies from food limitations. Whatever they cannot get from animal sources, they can just get it from plants, like Vitamin C. However, a vegan diet is limited and does have to worry about deficiencies from the limitations. Vitamin B12 does not have an adequate substitute in vegan sources, because it is not bioavailable, even with microbial food sources like algae.

The negation of veganism is not a diet made exclusively of animal products, but a diet not excluding animal products. The fact that a diet consisting exclusively of animal products is not nutritionally adequate, bears no relevance in this discussion.

Due to the antimicrobial treatment of livestock feed - preventing microbes from creating ingestible nutrients such as vitamin B12 - animal products are less nutritious now than they have been previously.
Farmed meat is not the only meat available. Free-range and hunted animals are still an option.
Vegan foods have too low bioavailability (compared to animal products) to provide nutrients lost through diarrheal disease, which is highly common and can be very serious in developing countries.
Diseases such as norovirus ultimately lead to undernutrition and, commonly, death in developing countries with a lack of sanitation.

People and agriculture are not evenly distributed across the globe, and many humans, especially those in poverty, living in food deserts. These people do not have as easy access to the variety of plant foods and supplements required to sustain a vegan diet as more privileged individuals.
Lesser privileged individuals living in food deserts would need to pay more for their vegan products, which would become a hardship than those living near them.

Due to the inconvenience, people in food deserts have more health issues. People there may still go for unhealthy items (like alcohol and fast food), even if those options are suddenly veganized, which makes removing these issues difficult.
Food deserts are not doomed to be food deserts forever. As technology changes, new solutions may be found to make food (including vegan food) more readily available in these areas.

Starches grow in practically any climate, and it's known which types cultivate well in each region. Being such a universal crop, they're a solution for providing nutrition and variety to food deserts.
Nutritionally and biologically speaking, a vegan diet is healthier for and better-suited to humans than a non-vegan one.
A vegan diet may help mitigate the risk of certain lifestyle diseases.

Restrictive diets are generally associated with long-term health benefits, as calorie restriction (frequently seen in veganism) is associated with longevity. Non-restrictive diets such as unlimited eating are commonly linked with many age-associated diseases like heart disease, dementia, cancer and diabetes.
A vegan diet can help prevent heart disease.
A modified vegan diet has scientifically been proven to treat and reverse coronary artery disease (CAD).
When dairy fat was replaced with the same number of calories from vegetable fat or polyunsaturated fat, the risk of cardiovascular disease dropped by 10% and 24%, respectively.

High-protein diets such as the one followed by Inuits exposes them to heart disease issues and a short life expectancy in contrast to diets using less meat such as the Okinawan diet which enables people to live over 100.
LDL Cholesterol-raised diseases contribute to millions of deaths every year in the western world, and a vegan diet would have helped prevent them.
Vegans have significantly reduced risk of ischemic heart disease compared to people following an omnivorous diet.
Saturated fats raise LDL cholesterol and the majority of saturated fat comes from animal sources.
Healthy diets can prevent cholesterol-caused diseases, so they don't need to be vegan to accomplish this.
Any specialized diet would prevent cholesterol caused diseases. Most people have very bad diets and having any dietary lifestyle would be beneficial.
A vegan diet lacks dietary cholesterol - the main cause of heart disease: the #1 killer worldwide.

After going vegan, people can still eat some of the unhealthy aspects of an omnivore's diet (such as excess saturated fats, sugars, and salt). For someone's diet to be healthier, they will have to eliminate animal products as well as vegan foods that trigger heart disease.
Vegan and vegetarian diets have been associated with a lower risk of Type 2 diabetes (pp. 62-63).
A whole-food plant-based diet that excludes animal products and refined foods is beneficial for preventing and treating type 2 diabetes.

Recent research is controversially showing that diets high in animal protein and fat and severely limiting carbohydrates are long term a better option for type II diabetics than diets high in complex carbohydrates and low in fats.
The consumption of some animal products has been linked to an increased risk of cancer.
