Veganism is based around the non-consumption of animal products. There are no other certain political or ethical elements of such a decision that suggest an increased interest in local produce.
Some countries rely on meat and fish for their economies (such as Iceland, Seychelles, and Mauritius). The removal of demand for their products would lessen human development in these regions.
Replacing all non-food animal products would be extremely expensive for individual consumers.
Ethical fashion brands - which include vegan fashion - are often very expensive.
If we all chose to stop buying products made by or with animals, the economy would give more attention to the vegan industry and the vegan product’s prices would be lower.
People would not necessarily have to replace their non-vegan products right away; just when they need replacing.
Any change will involve (short-term) costs in transitioning to the new system. Thus, by that logic, any change wouldn't be worthwhile.
Technological innovations could take place to advance a vegan society.
Biofuel is a great technology that a could improve a vegan society's current fuel resources.
Biofuel is better than other fuels, as it does not contain sulfur/aromatic compounds that other fuels contain.
Biofuel is so new and advanced, that this vegan industry can generate skilled jobs.
This could allow the people that lose employment in non-vegan industries to gain them in the vegan ones.

People currently working in the meat industry as labourers could switch to a 'vegan' job that makes an equal amount of money and is similar to their mode of work and industry so they don't notice the difference: like a janitor and floor sweeper of a slaughterhouse could be one for a fruit packer, a butcher of animals turn into one for produce chopper in a grocery store, etc.
Workers would have trouble applying their meat-processing skills in other (i.e. vegan) industries, because they aren't transferable.
Abattoir workers, who are trained in slaughtering animals, will not be able to transfer their training into a vegan context.
There is not an analogous role or skill set for butchers in a vegan context.
Butchers cut and trim animal carcasses down into recognizable cuts of meat. This is not necessary when it comes to vegan produce.
To switch jobs would mean losing out on wages temporarily, which would be a loss of money altogether, even if the wages are equal.

Grains and legumes make up the majority of a vegan diet's protein and calorie content. Those are very inexpensive food items that are often available in bulk (reducing the price further), making them better suited for people with unstable income.
Anybody with access to a small patch of land could grow fruits or vegetables, lessening their reliance on shop-bought food products.
A balanced vegan diet is cheaper than a balanced diet that includes meat.
Some NGOs who fight hunger across the world only provide vegetal foods. Main reason is the lower cost.
A study comparing a healthy diet that included meat, and a healthy diet that did not, found that the non-meat diet saved over $700 a year.
This study is geographically constrained to the USA, so it cannot be used to support the claim that a vegan diet is cheaper everywhere.

Experimenting to find the right vegan foods can be expensive, as it is inefficient and wasteful in finding what to eat (for instance, the cost of throwing out food that does not taste nice or turns out not to be vegan is pricier than just buying what is known to work).
Diets need not be changed suddenly. One who wants to become vegan can gradually incorporate more vegan foods until they find a complete vegan diet they like.
Recipes and recommended diets can be made available to those new to veganism to reduce or eliminate experimentation.

Meat can be bought in bulk too, making meat cheap too. Buying in bulk to save on price is not food-specific. Buying meat in bulk (reduces its subsidized price further) helps those with an unstable income buy it.
The demand for vegan products creates new vegan industries which will increase employment.
Animal-based companies worldwide are already profiting in the production more vegan-friendly products.
Large corporations like Unilever and McDonald's have developed vegan products.
The global vegan food industry is expected to consistently grow from 2021-2026.

The move to veganism would cause mass unemployment as farming, beekeeping, meat processing, and many other jobs would end. This would cause mass poverty, much like deindustrialisation has done already but on a larger scale.
One can argue for keeping every industry alive for the sake of jobs, no matter how harmful. Under this premise, we could never achieve progress and change.
This would be a short term effect and would not (in and of itself) make society worse off in the longer term, especially if replaced by other industries which may require more or less labour inputs.

Ultimately the same amount of food would need to be produced. As such demand for workers in non animal based farming would increase. Varieties of non-animal products would also increase to account for the diversity of products desired by consumers (think about the variety of crisps or candy currently in the market place) this would result in emergence of various niche non animal products and related industry. A good example is faux leather made from mycelium.
Business will adapt as they always do. This move to veganism would come on several generations so there is time for market to adapt and to do the transition.
A person's inability to adhere to a moral principle (i.e. veganism) does not affect the validity of the principle.
There have been situations where survival required consumption of humans, and yet, we strive for a society without cannibalism.

People usually resist something because they don't want to do it, rather than that they can't. Cigarette and health laws are difficult to change, due to a profit incentive, when most laws are changed practically on a whim these days. It's all relative, based on effort and priorities.
The Ought Implies Can principle illustrates that one cannot say "humans should be vegan" unless it can be established that they actually can.
The "Ought Implies Can" argument is widely debated, and is challenged by the "Is-Ought Problem" argument.

When it comes to dietary change as radical as switching to veganism, inability to adhere may be due to more than a weakness of morality or willpower, but rather an innate and instinctual drive against the principle.
It is likely easier to overcome issues of morality or willpower than it is to go against one's biological instincts.
Many people fail to quit smoking using willpower alone, and must receive external aid.
There is little or no scientific evidence for any innate and instinctual human drive against the principle 'all humans should be vegan'.
This doesn't mean we are morally justified to act on that drive.
We also have a drive to sexually reproduce, however there exist a number of moral and legal precepts on how we act on that drive.
Veganism is, by definition, flexible and thus feasible for most people and circumstances.
The fact that there are increasing numbers of people alive today who don't eat meat or who are already vegan is evidence that change is possible.
In the Indian subcontinent, a large fraction of society became largely vegetarian a long time ago, before free communication at scale as we have today.
The number of vegetarians in India is so large, that it would be the third largest country in the world today.

This change occurred for religious reasons. In a modern secular and multicultural world, it would be impossible to inspire the commitment needed to make an even greater change such as switching a society to veganism, without appealing to faith and religion.
If veganism were "too hard" no one could go vegan. Yet, tens of millions of people are vegan already and millions more will in just 2019 alone.
Claiming that "some can do it, therefore everyone can do it" is fallacious.
Many personal accounts support the argument that veganism can be a healthy and fulfilling lifestyle.
Real personal experiences and preferences in allowing veganism in their lives reveal that it is unrealistic and impractical for some in reality.
There are 5x times as many ex-vegans as there are vegans with almost 2/3 of them not interested in re-adopting veganism. Such ratios make it unlikely that all or most humans would become vegan.
Whether or not people are likely to become vegan is irrelevant to whether or not people ought to become vegan.
Aspiration does not infer anything about feasibility. A person can have the means of becoming vegan even though they do not wish to be.
People can make minimal, practically unnoticeable vegan substitutions to their non-vegan lifestyle; so they won't notice enough to worry or miss out on its favorable aspects.

As technology advances, it is increasingly feasible for many products that people mistakenly assume are vegan (but that actually contain animal products) to be made vegan without affecting quality or taste.
Switching out non-vegan consumer products to vegan ones is possible to accomplish and easier than ever.
Leather is an inessential clothing material that can be replaced by plant fibers if everyone went vegan.

Because leather is a byproduct of the meat industry, it is a waste not to use it. However, if everyone went vegan, there would be no worries of wasting resources (because the meat industry would not exist to create such byproduct).
People can make vegan choices for spaces they occupy without compromising quality and integrity.
Faux fur rugs can replace traditional fur rugs.
Vegan cosmetics exist.
People can buy soap bars without tallowates, such as castille soap bars.
Vegan jewelry, like gemstones (excluding amber), bamboo beads, twine, seeds, and porcelain could replace non-vegan ones.
Vegan options are available for some carnivorous pets.
Veganism should not involve changing the diet of animals who require animal products, like cats, to a diet unnatural to them.
Meat production cannot be stopped unless we stop keeping pets that require this food source altogether, which is unlikely to happen (as people like and want pets).
Many non-food items contain irreplaceable animal products, for example personal computers. Animal products are used in multitude of products nobody really thinks of.
Supposedly vegan foods might have hidden non-vegan components on them, even though the end product is vegan itself, like shellac and gelatin on bananas.
These non-vegan components can become a health risk, especially if a person is avoiding non-vegan foods due to allergies (such as the gelatin and possibly shellac (1, 2) on bananas).
Many of these vegan or vegetarian alternatives are more processed than their meat counterparts. Heavily processed foods tend to be less healthy than alternatives.
If one makes meat alternatives at home (like a raw veggie patty), then it would require less processing than a meat patty (which requires packaging and cooking).
The definition used here is pragmatic, rather than dogmatic, and thus is actually easier to follow than other forms of veganism.
Many of the difficulties associated with going vegan today would no longer arise if everyone were to go vegan.

If everyone is vegan, those who find it difficult will have an infrastructure and support system to help them through the ups and downs of a vegan diet. So it may be impossible in this world, but not so much in a vegan society.

Due to globalization, the more people go vegan worldwide, the cheaper vegan products (due to greater availability) will become to the consumer until lesser privileged societies overall would be able to afford it.

Due to effects of international specialisation in a globalized world, an increased demand for plant foods will cause their prices to rise, which in turn will force poor communities to export them while eating cheaper meat and dairy alternatives themselves.
While it is hard to follow at first and takes a while to adjust, once one starts to notice feeling better from it, it will get easier.
The cut-offs of what constitutes a vegan product are difficult to delineate and thus hard to follow.
There is not a clear boundary between an animal product and a non-animal product.
For certain foods, like oyster mushrooms, the debates clustered around it shape the list of what is vegan and what is not.
Some vegans, like Jains, do not believe that unicellular organisms are vegan, as it's a lifeform too that would be harmed if consumed.

The cutoff could stop at the naturally-created molecular level for it to be vegan. An example is if an animal's products become molecular naturally (like breathing out CO2) and not an exploitative source (like growing animals for CO2 production) and becomes indistinguishable from the same molecules not from animals (like CO2 from volcanoes), it is vegan. If animal remains are intact (like non-decomposed bones), then those are not vegan.

This is a definition that is workable, as some animal-specific molecules are distinguishable from non-living sources, such as collagen. This means that a manufacturer cannot break down an animal into molecular components and call it vegan.
Ambergris is a naturally expelled animal product and yet is still classified as 'non-vegan'.
The definition of intact vs. not intact remains is anthropocentric. Thus this prioritizes our own interests over the interests of animals, which is counter to the core tenets of veganism.
This definition includes anything that is not an animal: fungi, plants, cyanobacteria, etc.
Taxonomic classifications can help to determine whether a biological cell (to eat) is vegan or not.

Determining cells individually is really helpful in the definition of veganism. This is helpful especially in difficult situations like unicellular organisms, like protist colonies and chromists. They do not seem vegan when just looking at them (looks like one organism), but at the cellular level, they are.

If the single cell (the basic unit of life) comes from an animal source (like cultured meat or eggs), then it is not vegan. If it comes from unicellular organisms (like spirulina, a cyanobacteria), plants, fungi, or other non-animal source, then it is vegan.
A stated goal of veganism is to reduce animal suffering. However, "suffering" is too vaguely defined.
Veganism is more demanding on nutritional education of someone trying to adhere to it on a daily basis.

Just like how children are taught life skills (like how to eat, dress, etc.) when growing up, either by school, parents, or life, they could be taught how to properly balance their nutritional levels and have enough practice that they'll be at an expert-level quick and early enough to not incur potential damage.
Choosing to follow a restrictive diet can make it harder to engage with social events, as eating in restaurants is more difficult.
If everyone was vegan then eating in social groups would no longer be problematic.

Many restaurants, cafes etc. are widely expanding the variety and range of vegan foods that are available. Choosing a vegan dish when at a social event is becoming easier, and even if you have to bring your own or modify a dish, often the venue owners are quite open minded to the idea of expanding their menu to meet the needs of potential customers.
The vegan diet ranks abysmally on the top 40 most popular diets when ranking by convenience, tying for 36th place. The vast majority of popular diets are far more convenient than veganism.

'Quick food' options, like fast food restaurants and convenience stores, have very few (if any) vegan choices. Most of a vegan's diet realistically must be made rather than bought. For people with particularly busy lifestyles, this inconvenience can be a deal-breaker.
Veganism isn't "all or nothing". Going vegan means going as vegan as is practicable, and not further. If availability or convenience is an issue, adjustments can be made accordingly.
If people perceive veganism to be hard to accomplish, then it is irrelevant how easy it actually is. People's perception on a topic is a factor that may influence their behaviour.
A study found that the performance of participants on a test was significantly better when participants were told that the test was easy compared to participants who were told it would be difficult.
On large societal issues, it is extremely difficult to change people's minds.
Often large societal change, such as revolution, civil war or the election of a radical government can happen in a rapid, discontinuous manner.
There is no quick and easy fix for humanity's largest challenges. Abandoning progress altogether because of that would not make sense.

The change doesn't need to be all at once. Just eating less meat and gradually transitioning to vegetarianism is a progress in itself, so that everyone can get used to each adjustment along the way until we all get there.

The fact that something is difficult is not an excuse. If a person defers to the idea of it being the case, that is a choice in itself, a self-enacting postulate, and in essence amounts to active self-deceit based on either weakness, laziness, lecherousness, spite, or immorality - all of which are reprehensible in the context. A person can do it, it is a matter of them effectively choosing not to.

It doesn't have to be all or nothing. It is reasonable to expect the average person to abide by veganism to the extent they are able whilst placing the main burden on the politicians to drive the socio-political changes creating more accessible vegan options.
People can have inaccurate perceptions. If so, effort can be made to give a more accurate perception.
Following the ethical logic of veganism creates a high moral standard that humans would struggle to adapt to.
If everyone in the world were to become vegan, it would be an economical disaster destroying multi-trillion dollar industries.
The lack of crop diversity in the food marketplace could lead to serious food shortages due to crop failure, which could further lead to malnutrition and ultimately plagues.
Dietary freedom is an inalienable human right.
Society should protect, and not get in the way of, an individual's freedom of choice.
A vegan society would restrict people's individual liberties, which would make society worse off overall.

A society that safeguards individual liberties is more likely to be pluralistic. Such pluralism is beneficial by allowing a balanced decision process and access to diverse outcomes, e.g. moving towards a vegan lifestyle while eating much less meat or only eating it at traditional festivities.

When people cannot be independent, then they are more dependent on whomever thinks for them (in this case, the government). Thus, the world being vegan would turn countries into nanny states, so citizens become more reliant on the government for decisions.

The movement countries towards nanny states could set its citizens up for failure. When the government stops being there for its people, then people will not be able to take care of themselves anymore (because their thought capabilities were taken away), which limits their capability of surviving in the world.
Restricting liberties would limit one's autonomy, which is a barrier to an individual's independence. This issue should be avoided at all costs.
Killing some animals for food is an example of a human liberty.
In the longer term, not restricting people's individual liberties would make society worse off because non-veganism has environmental, animal, and human victims.
Individuals don't have the liberty to own slaves, rape, kill others, defecate in public transport, or drive while under the influence, etc. Yet these societies are not worse off because of it.
Some people feel the need to eat meat (both for health or for their body asking for it). It's unfair to prohibit it.
Meat cravings are common even among vegans themselves, forcing them to invent workarounds for this need.
Consuming animal products is healthy.

Animal products have benefits for appetite, metabolism, iron absorption and the health of your muscles. While you may find these in vegetables it doesn't change that they can be gained from a healthy meat diet. Just because vegetables are healthy doesn't mean meat isn't.
A diet that fits the human metabolism is guaranteed to provide all the nutrients we need.
Meat is an excellent source of iron (Pereira & Vicente, 2013), while milk-based products are an excellent source of calcium and fatty acids (Pereira, 2014).

It's not obvious that there's anything specifically beneficial about eating meat, and a healthy person with modest financial resources in an industrialized country can easily meet all normal dietary requirements on a vegan diet.
As vegans tend to make healthier lifestyle choices, consuming animal products should be less healthy than going vegan by association alone.
WHO (World Health Organisation) deems processed meat carcinogenic and red meat a probable carcinogen.
Meat has powerful stimulating effects on human sensory pleasure.
We should not transition to vegan foods if they do not taste better than meat (as some vegan foods taste worse than meat).
The problems associated with meat eating (e.g. animal mistreatment and environmental impact) massively outweighs the importance of the taste of our food.
Compassion for the suffering of other beings has greater moral importance than the relative enjoyment that humans get from eating.
Compassion, as a kind of reciprocal altruism, has evolved in conjunction with species identification.
This a false equivalency. You do not have to replace steak by a perfect vegan copy, you can find meals that you like just as much and that happen to be vegan.
It's the spices, i.e. plants, and thermic processing that make meat taste good. Raw meat is inedible for most.
Many children will remember being coaxed or forced to eat certain things even if they didn't like them, including some meats and meat products, causing them to dislike the taste.
Taste is subjective.
People's taste buds change to their diet (1, 2), so one day their body (i.e. their tongue and brain) will stop asking for meat.
Many people dislike the taste of meat, eggs, milk or cheese. It's subjective.
Taste is not the only thing driving people's desire for specific foods. People can get cravings for meat due to their gut bacteria.
The need to eat meat is neither desirable nor immutable.
Once people find vegan methods to address the health and craving concerns, then the need for animal products will stop being there.
Meat creates toxic metabolites that have a stimulating effect, followed by a 'hangover' feeling, that may cause people to become addicted.
Choice only makes sense if people's actions do not affect anyone else's. Once it affects others, people's choices do not get to be entirely their own.
Society must always place limits on freedom of choice, otherwise individuals could make decisions that would harm others.

There will always be a point where one person's choices will limit the ability of another to access their rights, or limit their choices. This is why we value certain rights above our freedom of choice (e.g. right to life, liberty etc.).

Limitations on dietary freedom are morally distinct from other limitations on free choice because we do not generally consider animals to be part of our society, but rather as a means by which our society and the individual is sustained. Carnivorism therefore does not harm any specific group within society.
People often consider companion animals such as cats and dogs to be family members. Therefore we ought to consider farm animals as part of our society by extension of the role which they play in it.
Many people gain substantial happiness from their non-vegan diet.

People that gain happiness from a vegan diet don't necessarily overlap with people that gain happiness from non-vegan diet. In such situation, letting everyone stick with their current preferences is a better idea if you want to keep more people happy.
The demand for meat is increasing. This shows its popularity.
Increasing demand for meat by developing countries is likely to plateau and then decline as they catch up with developed ones, whose meat-eating practices are declining.
The demand for meat could be tied to the subsidization of meat products, resulting in them being cheaper than plant based food, not necessarily to their popularity.

If so many people are happy with eating meat, then so many people (namely millennials) would not be trending away from it. Apparently people are not happy with the omnivore diet as they become more aware of the downsides of it, and are taking action to avoid it for better alternatives (like veganism).
From an hedonistic point of view, attaining pleasure is the only thing worth doing.
Kialo discurssion:     Hedonism is an appropriate lifestyle choice.
Vegans miss out on fulfilling experiences conducive to wellbeing.
Humans would not be able to interact with nature in a fulfilling and exciting way, which would make society worse off overall.

People learn about animals through non-vegan activities, like eating meat, having pets, visiting zoos, and hunting. Taking those activities away would make vegans less aware of animals due to less interactions with them.
Being up close and personal with animals can foster compassion and sympathy towards more animals than not being near them.
Being near animals can help organizations bring animal-related issues to the public's attention, especially at zoos.

These are artificial interactions. Vegans will create a better learning experience for understanding animals, because they will see them with natural behavior and form. This process will create a better understanding and appreciation than forced animal encounters.
People do not need to partake in non-vegan activities to learn about animals when the information is available in books and technology (which gets better each year).
Many people may be repulsed if they consider the ethical repercussion of an animal dying so that they can learn, such as with biology dissections.
Meaningful learning requires an emotional relationship, most prefer that of direct, personal experience. Dissections optimize education.
If people never ate meat, they would be deprived of a potentially fulfilling experience.
People are not entitled to something solely on the basis that it is fulfilling. A rapist probably gets fulfilment from raping. That does not mean he is entitled to do so.
If someone never ate meat, they wouldn't miss it.
Choosing to remain abstinent from something that is (potentially) harmful is not the same as deprivation.
Often, people don't know about many other foods and are therefore deprived of a fulfilling experience.
Hunting and fishing are examples of interacting with nature in a fulfilling and exciting way.

The notion that a fulfilling and/or exciting way to interact with nature must imply restraining, exploiting or killing animals is unfounded. There is no reason to think (and certainly there is no evidence) that vegans, on average, interact with nature in a less fulfilling and/or exciting way compared to non vegans.

There are many possibilites of interacting with or learning about nature that do not require killing or exploiting animals - like going visiting wildlife parks, hiking / mountain climbing, photography, visting museums, watching nature documentaries, working at animal shelters.
People can have vegan activities that fill their time just as well as non-vegan ones.
People could replace non-vegan hobbies, like hunting, fishing, beach-combing, and building aquariums, with vegan ones like kayaking, yoga, genealogy, and robotics.
Instead of going to zoos and animal circuses, one could be around animals by visiting nature (like a national park, sanctuary, or nature reserve) or viewing it through a webcam.
Even in zoos, animals have been known to injure and kill humans. Therefore, zoos and animal circuses are not necessarily any better than visiting nature.

The costs associated with visiting potentially dangerous animals in the wild (security, prevention, weaponry, aid, vehicles etc) may outweigh the benefits (e.g. client visits and investment) and may therefore be financially unsustainable.
The appearance of alternatives doesn't negate the evidence of restrictions.
As the technology improves, synthetic meat substitutes will inevitably become more economical, more nutritious, and better tasting than natural meat products.
Many vegan products already taste good, it's just that many people don't know it.
Just because broccoli tastes good doesn't mean we can't have ice cream.
The specific diet and lifestyle of an animal has a dramatic effect on its flavour, this would not be easy to replicate in a laboratory.

Laboratory produced food means that some laboratories will have food monopolies. Thus poor countries will have to pay extortionate amounts to buy food that they won't be able to produce by themselves, because their production of it is not vegan.

If lab food is produced at a rate that exceeds consumption, post-scarcity would be achieved. The technology to produce meat in this way should be public knowledge for the world to use. It should be a public service, first provided by the government, and private entities can sell their own product to attempt to compete with the government's free product. If they fail, capitalism will have taken one more step toward its demise.

While synthetic meat substitutes may be feasible, these means won't be economical for a long time. To get truly nutritionally equivalent meat at a similar price could take decades, as this start-up discusses by describing their meat substitute and their pricing projections for the future.
People should not have a right to do whatever pleases them regardless of consequences.
The happiness is just a mask for the addiction to animal products.
If meat addicts change their diet, their tastebuds will change with it, and then they won't feel the need to eat meat anymore.

Much of the happiness comes from generational and cultural traditions including shared diet and dishes used in celebrations or rituals. To reduce that to addiction overlooks the role food plays in people's lives.

Happiness from good food is not limited to meals containing animal products. Most of the time, it's about interesting textures, umami and the social aspect of eating together. By focusing on those essential aspects of eating out / eating together, people can gain comparable happiness on a vegan diet.
Veganism is a choice and should not be forced on children until they are old enough to decide for themselves.

A child will look up to the parents for guidance (like when they lie, can't forgive someone, steal, or when they choose to or not to eat meat). So parents can provide their advice to them when they are ready for it, so their children can make decisions for themselves based on what they hear.

Parents can raise a child in accordance with their own values. Parents act as a moral compass and make decisions based on morality for their children until they're old enough to make their own, better decisions.

If a child’s behaviour is unseemly to the parent, they are justified to reprimand the child accordingly. This includes if the child is doing something unethical in the eyes of the parent (like choosing to eat meat).

Children are told what is right and what is wrong by their parents, but if a parent thinks that stealing is ok, they still can't raise their child that way. Forcing a child to think a certain way when they are young and impressionable can make them never able to realize if they like meat or not if they aren't allowed to try it.
It's really meat that's forced onto children, as everyone gets into eating meat through parental choosing and cultural conditioning reinforcement and advertisement later.

Children are often not educated on the source of their food and distracted from their natural empathy for animals. The artificial divide between animals which are okay to eat and those that are not begins with parenting.
Since babies and young children cannot decide what they eat, to suggest that meat eating is 'forced' upon them is completely subjective, depending on your particular morals.
Our circumstances dictate what foods we eat, even if we are free to choose anything we want.
Humans will not be able to have a choice when meat runs out anyway (such as when every fish gets caught in the ocean, when a species goes extinct, or resource scarcity forces it).
Animals reproduce, some very quickly. Sustainable farming practices realistically preclude the possibility of a livestock species going extinct, including fish.
Every culture limits the freedom of choice regarding meat consumption, with some animals being considered improper for consumption.
With all humans being vegan, we would create worldwide limits on the freedom of choice for meat consumption, because all animals would be considered improper.

Humans should be able to choose to eat anything they like, like dogs, cats, apes, other humans etc, but can't because they aren't allowed to. In meat eating societies, they have bans on these, because these actions are offensive to others or problematic.
If people can eat meat from livestock, then it is no different than consuming these other animals. People just have moral/ethical instead logical conflicts with eating meat from these sources.
There are distinct emotional and cultural values attached to companion animals such as dogs and cats. Just because these concerns are moral or ethical do not mean they are worthless.

There are no problems inherent with eating any of those animals, but they cannot be lumped together with cannibalism, which is a completely different thing. Humans should, in fact, be able to choose to eat anything they like, short of committing a crime.
There is nothing inherently wrong with eating dogs, cats, or apes. Some cultures already do, and it presents no genuine problems for them.
Cultural limitations on human freedoms are sometimes wrong.
The amount of people who support/oppose certain actions does not speak for or against the action.
Unless you count cannibalism, Western culture doesn't really care what you eat.
Eating pets, endangered species, like apes, and cannibalism are all banned in many Western countries.
People eating endangered animals, such as apes, could be devastating to the environment if they go extinct.
There are multiple examples of traditional meats and animal products in Europe that could be considered improper by non-Europeans. These include fermented shark, haggis inter alia.
People aren't completely free to choose what to eat since advertising is prominent in our culture, affecting the decision making process.

Human bodies generally do not need any animal products to survive. Marketers just generated that myth just to make money regardless of their product's' health impact (like Got Milk commercials saying that calcium is needed from milk when the food with the most calcium is dried basil).
We should limit actions of humans which have negative effects on other humans. For example, the environmental impacts of animal agriculture.
Human rights are not circumstantial as they are inalienable. Any discrimination in access to food as well as to means and entitlements for its procurement is a violation of the right.
According to this argument, even cannibalism should be permitted. There have to be certain restrictions, and the premises of these should be up for debate.

Individuals should not be free to eat other humans, thus there are limitations to what someone is allowed to eat. Vegans would argue that some of the same reasons cannibalism should be forbidden would apply to forbidding eating animals.
Whilst humans are indeed biological creatures (apes, mammals, animals etc), there is a universally recognised separation of humans from animals in almost every subject and area.
Every society has acceptable, relatively agreed upon limitations on diet. The dietary freedom to eat meat is not equatable to the freedom to engage in, or a justification for, cannibalism.
While eating meat (and veganism) can contribute to health problems, eating other humans is proven to have much higher risks to health than either.
Eating human flesh is not associated with any higher risk than any other meat.
In history, in times of extreme famine and poverty, people have eaten other people, not out of desire, but out of necessity, deciding the benefits of not starving outweigh the risks.
Dietary freedom relies heavily on the notion of diet, which is relative. You can declare all animals as 'not food' just as easily, thus making the appeal to dietary freedom a circular argument.

What is considered to be 'food' is culturally contingent. If asked what food one can buy at a UK supermarket you will not be able to buy cat, dog or human, because, culturally, they are not food. Veganism is the understanding that animals qualify for the same taboo.
Prizing animals over other sources for protein is a man-made decision, not a natural one, especially with the discovery of fire.
Calling animals "not food" is equally fallacious as calling them food. Both are based one's opinion on the matter.
Veganism is incompatible with some religions, cultures and traditions.
Veganism may conflict with people's politics and ideologies.
Veganism contradicts humanism.
Humanism declares humans as the most valuable species while veganism explicitly condemns that as "speciesism" or "carnism".

Just because the focus of humanism is on human welfare, it does not follow that humans are assumed to be more important than animals. By this logic, cancer research charities, by virtue of being focused on cancer, think cancer is more important to eradicate than world hunger.

Vegans believe that humans' capacity for moral agency necessarily means a duty to protect animals and a guilt for exploiting them, while animals, by the virtue of lack of moral agency, are free from such duties or guilt. This basically means that humans are, from birth, naturally subordinate to animals, which directly contradicts humanism's rejection of such "original sin" or collective guilt of any kind.
Being obligated to protect someone does not necessarily make you subordinate to them. For instance, parents have a duty to protect their children, but are not subordinate to them for that reason.
Having a duty to protect someone does not infer any sort of guilt.
Veganism seeks to reduce unnecessary exploitation of animals, but does not impose a duty to protect animals.

Humanist ethics consider morality as an objective phenomenon and a social contract-like tool that moral agents establish and sustain in order to achieve well-being. Vegan ethics are utilitarian with their moralities revolving around min-maxing suffering that had been detached from moral agency.

Humanism affirms naturalism and embraces humans as a result of evolutionary change, while deriving ethical values from human interests as tested by experience. Thus humanism explicitly legitimizes the appeal to nature regarding humans, and makes humans' omnivorous diet a moral worth in itself.

Humanism is a fundamentally rational philosophy driven by compassion. Due to the environmental and well-being benefits of veganism, becoming vegan is, rationally-speaking, a compassionate thing to do for others and oneself.
Veganism is a western tradition and as such it would be neo-imperialist to impose it on non-western cultures.
Many non-Western cultures are vegan.
Many non-Western cultures, such as the Okinawans and Hunza, eat a plant-based diet.
Plant-based diets are common in India.
Per capita meat consumption in USA is 5 times that in India.

Veganism is not strictly a western dominant interpretation. For example, followers of Buddhism, Hinduism, and Jainism advocate vegetarianism in their culture, believing that humans should not inflict pain on animals.
Dharmic religions rely on dairy heavily, so they're not vegan.
In South Korea, for example, it is quite difficult to stay on a vegan diet as meat, fish and egg is very prevalent. For example, the stock for any Korean soup consists of dried anchovies.
As our understanding of umami ("meaty taste") and which compounds it's made of is constantly growing, we can develop tasty broths, condiments and sauces that don't require the use of animal flesh.
Granting fundamental rights to the inhabitants of a country, be they human or animal, is not imperialist, especially if these rights are not imposed by force.
Veganism is mostly aligned with left-wing ideologies. Those from moderate or conservative ideologies may feel that veganism is incompatible and inaccessible to them.

The central tenets of conservatism include tradition, organic society, hierarchy, authority, and property rights. Those who share any of these views will rarely be inclined to believe that animals have rights over humans, including the right not to be used as a commodity.
Animals are considered to be property in the law, which reflects authority, order and/or tradition for conservatives.
Eating animal products has been traditional around the world, which is especially true for conservatives.
Liberal nations such as Iceland (1) or Sweden (1) are far more likely to be interested in veganism.
US conservatives are less likely to go vegan or vegetarian than the US population as a whole.
Vegan conservatives exist, so having both is feasible.
The values of tradition, hierarchy, etc. could be created to protect animals if geared in that way: like creating a tradition to help animals and a hierarchy of humans being the protectors of them.
If everyone went vegan, since political ideologies are separated by more than one category, they would still exist, just with fewer lines of separation.
Some men feel that veganism undermines their masculinity.
Just 24% of vegans are men.
"Soy boy" is a common insult directed at vegan men who are perceived as weak and feminine.
Many men who want to reduce or avoid eating meat feel a sense of embarrassment and shame for doing so.
In western cultures, men often associate meat with strength and power, and hence masculinity.
Some prominent male combat sport combatants such as Nate Diaz are publicly vegan. Combat sports are exceptionally popular among men and emphasise traditional models of masculinity.
Some men consider their vegan diet to be an important part of a progressive masculinity that embraces feminist and intersectional veganism.
People's political and ideological beliefs often change over time.
Veganism conflicts with people's religious beliefs and practices.
Animal sacrifice is a component of some current religious practice.
Muslims have festivals involving head chopping of goats, such as Eid al-Adha, so veganism could hurt their sentiments.
In Christianity and Judaism, eating a lamb at Easter/Pesach is a several thousands years old tradition which symbolises the saving power of God.
A great deal of effort is put into ensuring that lamb will be available for Easter. This underscores the importance of this ritual.
There are 2.3 billion Christians and 14 million Jews in the world.
Substitutions can be made so people can still carry out their traditions. Faux lamb could be used instead of lamb to keep the traditions going.

Many religions already make substitutions in their practices (p. 3), which the religion allows for. With such flexibility, vegan substitutions should be possible and accepted, because of such commonplace that already takes place. If nobody can notice the difference in the substitution, then there is no reason not to use it.
Veganism is a worthwhile endeavour that justifies the loss of certain aspects of religious traditions.
The nature of the current meat industry is incompatible with cultural beliefs and traditions.
The teachings of Islam stress the importance of kindness and compassion for animals.
There is no way to express kindness and compassion through the systematic slaughter of animals for their meat.
Hinduism advocates for non-violence, which is directly contradicted in the harms committed by the meat industry.
There are a number of passages in the Old Testament that suggest actively countering animal suffering, and that advocate eating plant-based food.
The breeding practices, living conditions, and violence used in maximising output in the meat industry contradict the teachings of Christianity.
There are plenty of options for people of various faiths. Halal groceries, hunting, back yard farming are all reasonable options.
The meat industry being incompatible with cultural, or religious, values is not an argument to justify veganism. Instead it is a justification for making the meat industry more religion-friendly.
There is no feasible way to ethically put down billions of animals per year. The only realistic solution is to bring down meat demand.
Halal meat - seen by Muslims as the only ethical way to kill an animal - is widely practised throughout the world. Therefore, there is a feasible way to put down animals ethically according to Islam.
In the UK, the supply of halal meat outstrips demand, indicating it is highly feasible on a mass scale.
Halal is not a more ethical way to slaughter animals as it still needlessly takes the life of an animal with methods inflicting pain and suffering.
There are no prohibitions for eating meat in the 10 commandments. Therefore, it is not fundamentally incompatible with Christianity or Judaism.

Christianity teaches that God allowed mankind to eat certain animals, and there are even Biblical verses, when God suggests to eat them. Therefore, for a confessional Christian, eating certain animals is completely ethical.

There are instructions given by god in the Bible that were deemed necessary at that time and place, and yet, were not considered “completely ethical”. To assume that god instructed it and therefore it is ethical for all people at any time in any culture to perform that act is faulty.
Some people, such as Jainists, would prefer not to kill animals, even in extreme situations of survival (p. 1502).
Even if the world went vegan, many people might retain their meat-eating cultural beliefs and memories. For these people, a vegan lifestyle may be impossible to sustain long term.
Meat and dairy are important to some cultures.
Veganism is incompatible with Inuit culture, where sustainable and respectful seal hunting has been a part of their lives for centuries.

Seal hunting bans put in place by colonizers have created economic scarcity for Inuit people and forced them into multi-generational poverty. A global shift to veganism may have a similar impact on Inuit communities.
Since very little vegetation survives in the Arctic, if the Inuit were to switch to a vegan diet they would likely starve and possibly die.

If all humans became vegan, then humanity would lose a big part of its collective culture. Keeping around a small portion of the culture is desirable for educational settings, re-enactments, historians, etc.
The observation of a living system or experience of something directly (like eating meat) can be difficult to replicate entirely and may need to be around for educational purposes.

Although complete replication is virtually impossible, some methods (like recreation and simulation (e.g. virtually)) are close and realistic enough to not really require consuming animal products anymore to experience them.

Performative art and studying cultural heritage is possible without actually continuing to kill and eat animals. Just like people don't actually wage war or keep slaves for the sake of historical re-enactment.
Many cultures highly value traditional meals and recipes, which may not be possible to create in a vegan manner.
Progressing veganism for the benefit of humanity supercedes the priority of preserving culture.

Some cultural practices are unlikable by even the people within the culture, that they try to get away from it (1, 2). Keeping around something that even people in the culture do not want anymore and preventing something that people do want does not make logical sense.
Arguing against trying to protect the few areas and people that veganism doesn't apply to invokes the appeal to popularity fallacy, which is discriminatory.
The ongoing practise of traditional, local, culinary habits around the world has intrinsic value akin to world heritage sites.
In Mi’kmaq culture, the killing of a moose symbolized a boy’s entry into manhood. So when you challenge the hunting traditions, you’re challenging how Mi’kmaq men understand their masculinity.

Challenging cultures that are unethical is more important than preserving traditions. For instance, tiger body parts and elephant tusks are a common ingredient in Traditional Chinese Medicine but have been outlawed. Other cultural traditions include owning people as slaves.
Many traditional non-vegan dishes would be lost.
Many of the food and drink traditions recognised by UNESCO's Lists of Intangible Cultural Heritage contain meat, dairy or fish.
Human cuisine has always evolved, especially in recent years with the wider availability of different foods. The void that losing some traditional dishes creates can easily be filled.
Non-western cultures eat fewer animal products than western ones.
Just because something is tradition doesn't mean it's morally permissible and should be continued.
Traditions can and do change over time.

Various small and ancient cultures are getting lost/pushed out anyway to generationalism (or lack thereof), globalization, modernization, and its appeal. So even if veganism is incompatible with these cultural beliefs and practices, that would not be an issue in the future, as they won't be around for veganism to conflict with or disrupt them.
Cultures can preserve their practices by making substitutions with vegan ones without compromising its practices through assimilation, as it's most successful.

Veganism is a part of modernization, so it can exacerbate the removal of cultures. That makes it still incompatible with them, even if it doesn't clash with their beliefs and practices directly and in reality.

Even if cultural practices are lost from veganism, the cultures can be documented and preserved to practice the vegan parts when desired. This process allows cultures to progress freely in the positive direction without losing the cultures themselves (outside of the practice of them).
For example, slavery was once a tradition but is illegal today.
Slavery is still legal in almost half of the countries of the world.

Cultural traditions centered around meat (like hunting, ritual slaughter for certain spiritual / religious events) are not the main focus of veganism. Although vegan ethics would dictate the abolishment of such practices, the vegan movement is currently more concerned with animal agriculture on a large, global scale. A small native tribe owning a herd of goats is a relatively small problem and vegans are not trying to take away animals from people who actually depend on them.
Traditions that cause harm to sentient beings should be eliminated or replaced.
Eliminating harmful traditions will create a world filled with more happiness.
Many of these traditions require the process to be as painless and humane as possible.
Slaughter of animal using Kosher or halal rules makes the process as quick and painless as possible.
As the animal is not stunned before Kosher or Halal slaughter, the animal often reacts violently, showing that it is indeed painful.
No ritual slaughter technique is specifically designed to minimize suffering. Thus, all produce unnecessary suffering.
The gratuitous killing of a sentient being is never humane.
Since meat is not biologically necessary, the primary reason humans still eat meat is because of social conditioning which can be changed.
The more privileged societies go vegan, the more feasible going vegan will seem to less privileged societies/individuals.
Many people have tried becoming vegan after seeing popular celebrities doing the same.
Veganism is seen as a status symbol and a sign of privilege, due to its difficulty in attaining it. If everyone's vegan, it'll no longer be that way, which will make eating it more socially feasible.

Young children are born with a natural aversion towards harming animals (except in rare circumstances), including due to fearfulness. They get conditioned by people around them later on to act differently towards animals. Having less sympathy towards animals probably prepares them to be less cautious towards eating meat (even though animal aversion is in our nature).
Social conditioning with regards to meat-eating is difficult to change.
This does not mean we should eat meat, as people can be conditioned to like the taste of vegan foods as well.
A few generations ago, people were conditioned to be skeptical of homosexuality and still we have legalized gay marriage today. It is possible to change social conditioning.
